Submodules#

pygradethis.check_functions module#

This module contains functions to check function calls, standardize arguments, and return standardized call.

pygradethis.check_functions.standardize_arguments(left_call, right_call, left_source='', right_source='')#

This will standardize the function calls for a function Call and return the modified Call.

Returns None if there are no issues with the function call.

Otherwise, an error message is returned if the user code can’t be parsed, if there is a problem not finding variables in environment, or if arguments cannot be standardized.

Parameters

  • left_call (ast.Call) – the user’s function call to standardize arguments

  • right_call (ast.Call) – the solution function call to standardize arguments

  • left_source (str, optional) – the entire source code in which left_call belongs, by default “”

  • right_source (str, optional) – the entire source code in which right_call belongs the source code, by default “”

Returns

standardized function call

Return type

ast.Call

Raises

AssertionError – when there is an issue with the standardization process

pygradethis.conditions module#

class pygradethis.conditions.GraderCondition(*args, **kwargs)#

Bases: dict

Convience class to represent the a grader condition for an exercise.

Example:

GraderCondition(

x = x, message = message, correct = correct, type = type

)

pygradethis.conditions.python_condition(x, message, correct, type='value')#

Return the proper structure for a particular type of condition.

Return type

dict

pygradethis.conditions.python_fail_if(x, message='')#

Return a fail condition.

Return type

dict

pygradethis.conditions.python_pass_if(x, message='')#

Return a pass condition.

Return type

dict

pygradethis.feedback module#

This module contains utilities for generating a friendly message for feedback

pygradethis.feedback.encourage()#

Returns a random encouragement message

Return type

str

pygradethis.feedback.praise()#

Returns a random praise message

Return type

str

pygradethis.formatters module#

Module contains a generic AST node formatter and allows for custom formatters for whichever data type you need.

To define a node formatter simply define another _ function, register its type for the generic formatted function, and define the string to return:

``` @formatted.register(<your type>) def _(node: ast.AST) -> str:

<process your node> return “<your string>”

```

Alternatively, you can also call the format_node function to register your function using one of two ways:

  1. format_node(int, <”a string”>)

  2. format_node(int, <a function or lambda that formats and returns string>)

The basic data types and ast types have been supported but can be changed in the respective register function definition, or overriden with format_node.

pygradethis.formatters.format_node(node_type, string_format)#

Registers a format function for a give node type

The node_type must be a valid data type in Python. The string_format can be either a str or a function / lambda.

pygradethis.formatters.formatted(node)#

Generic function to return a formatted representation of an AST node

Return type

str

pygradethis.grade_code module#

This module is used to check if a user’s code is equal to solution code and note when the two differ.

pygradethis.grade_code.check_children(left, right, line_info, left_source='', right_source='', last_parent='')#

Checks children of two asts by iterating their fields

Parameters

  • left (ast.AST) – the student code

  • right (ast.AST) – the solution code

  • line_info (Dict[str, int]]) – holds line information about a particular node

  • left_source (str, optional) – the source text for user code, by default “”

  • right_source (str, optional) – the source text for the solution code, by default “”

  • last_parent (str, optional) – the nearest parent that can be converted to source text, by default “”

pygradethis.grade_code.check_functions(left_call, right_call, line_info, left_source='', right_source='', last_parent='')#

Standardizes and compares two ast.Calls. Raise AssertionError as soon as they differ.

Parameters

  • left_call (ast.Call) – the user function call

  • right_call (ast.Call) – the solution function call

  • line_info (Dict[str, int]]) – holds line information about a particular node

  • last_parent (str) – the nearest parent that can be converted to source text, by default “”

  • left_source (str) – the source text for user code, by default “”

  • right_source (str) – the source text for the solution code, by default “”

pygradethis.grade_code.compare_ast(left, right, line_info, left_source='', right_source='', last_parent='')#

Compare two abstract syntax trees. Raise AssertionError as soon as they differ.

Parameters

  • left (Any) – the student code

  • right (Any) – the solution code

  • line_info (Dict[str, int]]) – holds line information about a particular node

  • left_source (str) – the source text for user code, by default “”

  • right_source (str) – the source text for the solution code, by default “”

  • last_parent (str) – the nearest parent that can be converted to source text, by default “”

Return type

None

pygradethis.grade_code.compare_node(left, right, line_info, last_parent='')#

Compare two objects of the same type and raise an exception with feedback if nodes differ.

Parameters

  • left (Any) – an ast.Node, a custom type, or a python data type

  • right (Any) – an ast.Node, a custom type, or a python data type

  • line_info (Dict[str, int]) – holds line information about a particular node

  • last_parent (str) – the nearest parent that can be converted to source text

pygradethis.grade_code.compare_node_type(left, right, line_info, last_parent='')#

Compare two ASTs’ types and raise an exception with the line number if different.

Parameters

  • left (Any) – an ast.Node, a custom type, or a python data type

  • right (Any) – an ast.Node, a custom type, or a python data type

  • line_info (Dict[str, int]) – holds line information about a particular node

Return type

None

pygradethis.grade_code.grade_code(student_code, solution_code)#

Checks user and solution code and prints a message if they differ

Parameters

  • student_code (str) – the user source code

  • solution_code (str) – the solution source code

Returns

  • None – If there are no issues

  • str – If user code differs from solution

pygradethis.grade_code.new_parent_source(tree, last_parent)#

Given an ast, the current tree, and the last parent source, return a new last parent source for facilitating feedback on problematic node.

Parameters

  • tree (Any) – the ast.AST or a Python type we want to extract the source text for

  • last_parent (str) – the nearest parent that can be converted to source text

Returns

the new last_parent or the same

Return type

str

pygradethis.grade_result module#

This module is used to check python code output.

pygradethis.grade_result.python_grade_result(*conditions, user_result=None, unittest_style=False)#

This function checks the user’s code output against the list of conditions.

Parameters

  • conditions (*GraderCondition) – a variable number of GraderCondition objects

  • user_result (Any, optional) – user’s code output, by default None

Returns

dict, if there are no issues str, an error message if GraderCondition(s) is not supplied

Return type

Union[dict, str]

Raises

Exception – if GraderConditions are not passed in for conditions

pygradethis.message_generators module#

This module holds functions for common mistakes and generating messages for feedback to the student.

pygradethis.message_generators.missing(left, right, line_info)#

Generates message when user is missing a node or element in code.

Parameters

  • left (Any) – an ast.Node, a custom type, or a python data type

  • right (Any) – an ast.Node, a custom type, or a python data type

  • line_info (Dict[str, int]) – holds line information about a particular node

Returns

feedback message

Return type

str

pygradethis.message_generators.missing_argument(left_call, right_source, e)#

Generates a feedback when there is a missing argument for a function call.

Parameters

  • left_call (ast.AST) – student’s function call

  • right_source (str) – solution source text

  • e (TypeError) – the error object

Raises

AssertionError – to ripple up back to grade_code

Return type

None

pygradethis.message_generators.not_expected(left, right, line_info)#

Generates message when user supplies an extra node or element in code.

Parameters

  • left (Any) – an ast.Node, a custom type, or a python data type

  • right (Any) – an ast.Node, a custom type, or a python data type

  • line_info (Dict[str, int]) – holds line information about a particular node

Returns

feedback message

Return type

Return type

  • right_source (str) – solution source text

  • right_source (str) – solution source text

Return type

pygradethis.message_generators.wrong_value(left, right, line_info, condition, last_parent)#

Generates message when user’s code contains in an incorrect value.

Parameters

  • left (Any) – an ast.Node, a custom type, or a python data type

  • right (Any) – an ast.Node, a custom type, or a python data type

  • line_info (Dict[str, int]) – holds line information about a particular node

  • last_parent (str) – the nearest parent that can be converted to source text

  • condition (bool) – the condition we want to check regarding equality between left and right ast nodes or values

Returns

feedback message

Return type

str

pygradethis.python_grade_learnr module#

This is the learnr version of python_grader module and contains the python_grade_learnr function called by the gradethispython R wrapper package

pygradethis.python_grade_learnr.graded_learnr(result, condition)#
pygradethis.python_grade_learnr.python_grade_learnr(label=None, solution_code=None, user_code=None, check_code=None, envir_result=None, evaluate_result=None, envir_prep=None, last_value=None)#

This function mirrors the grade_learnr function from {gradethis} package so that we can check Python exercises. This function does two things: - Do static code grading (AST) if both user and solution code is provided

before the result grading.

  • Do result grading based on code output and GraderCondition(s)

Parameters

  • label (str, optional) – exercise label, by default None

  • solution_code (str, optional) – solution source code, by default None

  • user_code (str, optional) – user source code, by default None

  • check_code (List[str], optional) – checking code, by default None

  • envir_result (dict, optional) – environment containing execution results, by default None

  • evaluate_result (List[str], optional) – evaluation results, by default None

  • envir_prep (dict, optional) – environment associated with exercise, by default None

  • last_value (Any, optional) – the last value of exercise, by default None

Returns

a feedback dict: {

message = str, correct = True|False, type = “auto|success|info|warning|error|custom”, location = “append|prepend|replace”

}

Return type

dict

pygradethis.python_grader module#

This module contains functions to faciliate checking Python code or output.

pygradethis.python_grader.grade(*check_code, user_code=None, solution_code=None, unittest_style=False)#

Python standalone verson of python_grade_learnr. This function does two things: - Do static code grading (AST) if both user and solution code is provided

before the result grading.

  • Do result grading based on code output and GraderCondition(s)

Parameters

  • check_code (*GraderCondition) – a variable number of GraderCondition objects

  • user_code (str, optional) – user source code, by default None

  • solution_code (str, optional) – solution source code, by default None

Returns

a feedback dict: {

message: str, correct=True|False, type=”auto|success|info|warning|error|custom”, location=”append|prepend|replace”

}

Return type

dict

pygradethis.python_grader.graded(result, condition, unittest_style=False)#

class pygradethis.result_checker.TestCondition(test_name, condition)#

Custom TestCase to do asserts on GraderCondition(s) and incorporate custom asserts from libraries like pandas for dataframe checking.
